title: Four antenatal care visits by four months of pregnancy and four vital tests for pregnant mothers: impact of a community-facility health systems strengthening intervention in Migori County, Kenya
abstract: Abstract Background Early attendance at antenatal care (ANC), coupled with good-quality care, is essential for improving maternal and child health outcomes. However, achieving these outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa remains a challenge. This study examines the effects of a community-facility health system strengthening model (known as 4byFour) on early ANC attendance, testing for four conditions by four months of pregnancy, and four ANC clinic visits in Migori county, western Kenya. Methods We conducted a mixed methods quasi-experimental study with a before-after interventional design to assess the impact of the 4byFour model on ANC attendance. Data were collected between August 2019 and December 2020 from two ANC hospitals. Using quantitative data obtained from facility ANC registers, we analysed 707 baseline and 894 endline unique ANC numbers (attendances) based on negative binomial regression. Logistic regression models were used to determine the impact of patient factors on outcomes with Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) and likelihood ratio testing used to compare models. Regular facility stock checks were undertaken at the study sites to assess the availability of ANC profile tests. Analysis of the quantitative data was conducted in R v4.1.1 software. Additionally, qualitative in-depth interviews were conducted with 37 purposively sampled participants, including pregnant mothers, community health volunteers, facility staff, and senior county health officials to explore outcomes of the intervention. The interview data were audio-recorded, transcribed, and coded; and thematic analysis was conducted in NVivo. Results There was a significant 26% increase in overall ANC uptake in both facilities following the intervention. Early ANC attendance improved for all age groups, including adolescents, from 22% (baseline) to 33% (endline, p = 0.002). Logistic regression models predicting early booking were a better fit to data when patient factors were included (age, parity, and distance to clinic, p = 0.004 on likelihood ratio testing), suggesting that patient factors were associated with early booking.The proportion of women receiving all four tests by four months increased to 3% (27/894), with haemoglobin and malaria testing rates rising to 8% and 4%, respectively. Despite statistical significance ( p < 0.001), the rates of testing remained low. Testing uptake in ANC was hampered by frequent shortage of profile commodities not covered by buffer stock and low ANC attendance during the first trimester. Qualitative data highlighted how community health volunteer-enhanced health education improved understanding and motivated early ANC-seeking. Community pregnancy testing facilitated early detection and referral, particularly for adolescent mothers. Challenges to optimal ANC attendance included insufficient knowledge about the ideal timing for ANC initiation, financial constraints, and long distances to facilities. Conclusion The 4byFour model of community-facility health system strengthening has the potential to improve early uptake of ANC and testing in pregnancy. Sustained improvement in ANC attendance requires concerted efforts to improve care quality, consistent availability of ANC commodities, understand motivating factors, and addressing barriers to ANC. Research involving randomised control trials is needed to strengthen the evidence on the model’s effectiveness and inform potential scale up.

title: What drives currency connectedness? Evidence from the BRICS currencies
abstract: With the rapid growth of the BRICS countries, their currencies have attracted wide attention. This study examines the dynamic connectedness of BRICS currencies and identifies the drivers of currency connectedness using a time-varying vector autoregressive (VAR) approach and a modified dynamic model averaging method. Our results indicate that dramatic changes in the currencies' total and net connectedness are related to influential economic, financial, and political events. ZAR is a consistent net transmitter, INR and CNY are consistent net recipients, whereas BRL and RUB switched roles frequently. The risk and uncertainty indices, especially the VIX and SKEW, were the most pronounced drivers affecting the total and net connectedness among the selected drivers. The remaining factors (i.e. commodity prices, asset markets, and leading global currencies) generally had limited effects but played important roles in certain influential events.

title: Derivative Financial Instruments (Derivatives) in Hedging Practices of Non-Financial Organizations
abstract: The financial and economic situation in Russia in 2022 has sharply reduced the market for derivative financial instruments (derivatives), including the instruments applied by non-financial organizations (hedgers) to reduce commercial risks (hedging). At the same time, volatility in commodity markets and unilateral restrictive measures increase the risks of unforeseen property losses in connection with the execution of derivatives, which is why Russian non-financial organizations are increasingly trying to invalidate such contracts. However, a commonly used ground for contesting in many cases (violation of the requirements of a law or other legal act (Article 168 of the Civil Code of the Russian Federation)) turns out to be irrelevant, indicating a distorted understanding of the legal nature of derivative financial instruments and contradictory behavior of plaintiffshedgers. Their typical arguments are explained through the legal features of derivatives: the aleatory nature on which the distribution of monetary obligations of the parties and the uncertainty of the amount of monetary provision are based, and the lack of legal prerequisites for the universal presumption of asymmetry of the parties of the hedging derivative. The legal significance of volatility in the contractual structure of a derivative financial instrument is justified by the strict relationship between its regulatory aleatory nature and the random variability of the parameters of the underlying asset, the econometric characteristics of which do not affect the validity and effect of the contract. The author draws conclusions that unlimited property losses on a derivative are preconditioned not only by its aleatory nature, but also by the hedging objectives. It is noted that unconditional application of the concept of strengths and weaknesses in derivative financial instruments involving non-financial organizations is controversial due to various aspects of contractual and information asymmetry.

title: Price effects of commodity financialization: Review of the evidence
abstract: Abstract Following the 2007/2008 financial crisis, the price effects of commodity financialization have become an important research topic. We review the empirical evidence, focusing on statistical approaches and econometric models, and find that (1) Granger‐causality tests are unable to establish a relationship between commodity futures prices and funds of financial investors, implying a lack of evidence that financialization influences commodity futures prices and (2) studies that use correlation and price spread analysis mostly report evidence of a significant price effect of financialization. Thus, the statistical and econometric approaches adopted by the various studies influence the empirical findings. In addition, data identification may have an impact since economic models and statistical techniques can be sensitive to slight differences in the dataset. Our study of the literature shows that the definition of financialization is open‐ended and ambiguous. A theoretical literature review on financialization could be the logical next step.

title: Research on finance Credit Risk Quantification Model Based on Machine Learning Algorithm
abstract: Machine learning is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) technology that enables systems to learn and make predictions and decisions without the need for explicit programming. Machine learning algorithms learn patterns and relationships from data and are able to gradually improve their accuracy.This paper mainly introduces the application of deep learning in financial academia and the financial industry, with a particular focus on the application of machine learning and deep learning in financial quantitative trading. The paper mentions the complexity and challenges of financial markets and the difficulties machine learning faces in processing financial time series data, such as overfitting, non-stationarity, heteroscedasticity and autocorrelation. To overcome these challenges, the paper explores machine learning model design in financial quantitative trading and risk prediction, including data transformation and model construction. In the related work part, it introduces the history and development of quantitative investment, as well as the application of quantitative investment, such as high-frequency trading, arbitrage strategy and commodity trading advisory strategy. It then focuses on the application of machine learning in financial quantification, including the use of supervised and unsupervised learning in stock price forecasting and trading strategy generation. The paper also compares traditional quantitative strategies with machine learning strategies and discusses the advantages of machine learning in solving high-dimensional and non-linear problems. The methodology section introduces the application of the random forest model in financial quantification, including the model principle, feature importance calculation and experimental design. Through the pre-processing, feature selection and model construction of the credit risk prediction dataset, the construction and evaluation process of the random forest model is demonstrated. Finally, the performance of the random forest model is evaluated and compared with other models to demonstrate its advantages and applicability in financial quantification.

title: Inserção e instabilidade do capital internacional no setor sucroenergético brasileiro: uso corporativo e estratégias territoriais do Grupo BP Bunge Bioenergia
abstract: Driven by a financialized accumulation regime, Brazil experienced, at the turn of the 21st century, several economic, social and, therefore, territorial transformations, implying important changes in agricultural spaces.With the globalization of the economy, profound transformations arise in the production process associated with agriculture, restructuring the space due to the insertion of technique, science and information.It is from this recent context of agribusiness that we intend, in this doctoral thesis, to understand some specific dynamics of the sugar-energy sector (production of sugar cane and derivatives) in the country, specifically evaluating the dynamics that comprise the corporate use of the territory by the BP Bunge Bioenergy Group.In the current century, there has been a significant expansion of sugarcane cultivation in the country, mainly due to the increase in international demands for sugar and the possibilities of affirming ethanol as a new commodity, as a result of the concerns of different countries with global warming, in addition to the emergence of flex fuel technology.Such growth, however, has encountered certain limits since 2015, following the developments of the international financial crisis.It is in this context of crisis, stagnation and slow recovery of the sugar-energy sector that our central research concern emerges.The joint venture established by BP and Bunge, for the creation of BP Bunge Bioenergy, results in a probable strategy for the aforementioned groups to remain in the activities of the sugar-energy sector in an adverse situation, a way of survival in a scenario of stagnation that has prevailed in Brazil since mid-2010s, a situation that led the group to invest in even more intensive land use strategies, with extreme technical rationalization of production and flexible work.Aiming to face the adverse situation in which the sector finds itself, the BP Bunge Group adopts practices of extreme technical rationalization of production, the most significant aspect of which can be recognized in the speed with which the digitalization of production proceeds, as well as the practices of making work more flexibilization, and even its precariousness.These conditions appear necessary to avoid the devaluation of the capital mobilized by the two multinationals in the Brazilian sugar-energy sector.

title: MARKETING CHAIN ANALYSIS OF ORCHID PLANT (Case Study at the Bratang Flower Market, Gubeng District, Surabaya)
abstract: Background One of the easiest and most fertile types of beautiful flowering ornamental plants in Indonesia is the orchid. The business of orchids as a commercial flower that has high economic value has been going on for a long time, and has even become one of the important commodities in the world floricultural trade. The orchid business is currently quite developed, so that it will be able to increase farmers' income, meet the demands of environmental beauty, make residential, hotel and office complexes more beautiful. The aim is to determine the marketing chain of Orchids in the Bratang Flower Market, Gubeng District, Surabaya. Research Methods The type of research used in this research is the case study method, by taking the case of an orchid plant seller at the Bratang Flower Market, Gubeng District, Surabaya. Respondents as a whole are as many as 16 people. The analysis used in this research is descriptive qualitative analysis and quantitative analysis. Results The product flow pattern of the orchid marketing chain in the Bratang Flower Market, Gubeng District, Surabaya, has one channel that distributes products in the form of orchids, namely farmers selling orchids to collectors, then collecting traders selling to retailers and retailers then selling to consumers, financial flows flow from consumers To the retailer, the retailer flows to the collector, then the collector to the farmer and the flow of information that flows from the orchid farmer to the collector, the collector to the retailer and the retailer flows to the final consumer. This occurs in two interrelated directions. The distribution margin is IDR 0.19/Pot, the total marketing margin is IDR 5000/Pot. Orchid marketing efficiency at the Bratang Flower Market, Gubeng District, Surabaya, which is equal to 1.06%, it can be said that marketing of orchids in the research area has been efficient. The conclusion is that the distribution margin is IDR 5000/pot, the total margin is IDR 5000/pot. Orchid marketing efficiency at the Bratang Flower Market, Gubeng District, Surabaya, which is equal to 1.06%, it can be said that marketing of orchids in the research area has been efficient.

title: The impact of the Russo-Ukraine conflicts on price discovery on the financial markets
abstract: This paper investigates the response of financial markets to two significant events within the Russo-Ukraine conflicts: the November 2013 Euromaidan protest and the February 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. Employing diverse methods, including event studies, price discovery models, and time-varying parameter regression, we analyse abnormal returns, price discovery, time-varying herding behaviour, and market dynamics across various financial instruments, such as stock indices, currencies, and commodities. Overall, the Russian invasion of Ukraine had a more pronounced impact on financial markets compared to the Euromaidan protest. Moreover, during both events, the US dollar and yen consistently functioned as safe-haven assets. The findings also reveal variations in the responses of different assets to the conflicts, indicating potential effects on market efficiency, investor perceptions, and expectations.

title: Factors supporting sovereign wealth fund adoption
abstract: The adoption of sovereign wealth funds (SWFs) has been rising globally. While their benefits are recognized, they are underutilized, particularly among commodity exporters. This research adds to the nascent literature on factors, focusing on external support, institutional readiness, and domestic capability, that influence SWF adoption. We highlight the importance of international financial institutions, policy frameworks, and technical capability in supporting countries' adoption of SWFs.

title: Sentiment and energy price volatility: A nonlinear high frequency analysis
abstract: This study investigates the volatility dynamics of oil and gas prices in an environment characterized by post-coronavirus disease 2019 recovery, uncertainty, high inflation, and geopolitical tensions. Unlike previous studies, we examine a long-run series of high-frequency data on gas and oil prices from July 2007 to May 2022, which provides more than one million observations with which to analyze volatility. We compute realized volatility (RV) and decompose it into continuous volatility and jumps. We then investigate the relationship between uncertainty, investor sentiment, and RV, as well as its main components. Econometrically, we extend the heterogeneous autoregressive model of Corsi (2009) while considering not only disaggregate proxies for volatility (jumps and continuous volatility) and introducing uncertainty and heterogeneous investor sentiment, but also by allowing the model to include asymmetry, nonlinearity, and time variation according to the regime under consideration. Our results present three main findings. First, we find significant evidence of volatility decomposition, suggesting that both markets are characterized by significant jumps. Second, we show that trading volume, extra-financial news (uncertainty, investor sentiment), and jumps appear to drive commodity price volatility. Third, we find evidence of nonlinearity and threshold effects on energy price volatility. These findings are relevant for policymakers, regulators, investors, and portfolio managers, as they enable them to better characterize and forecast changes in commodity prices.

title: Guest Editorial: The social life of Chinese infrastructures in Southeast Asia
abstract: As part of the broader China Made project, the papers in this special section aim to provide grounded, fine-grained analyses of the environmental, social, cultural, political, and economic effects of China's infrastructure development initiatives in Southeast Asia.1 They were originally presented at the Third China Made Workshop in May of 2021, held online at the Asia Research Institute (ARI) at the National University of Singapore (see Byler & Oakes, 2021 for a summary). The papers in this special section explore the social lives of Chinese infrastructures with case studies from Vietnam (Turner et al., 2023), Cambodia (Green & Yi, 2023) and Laos (Harlan & Lu, 2024). In doing so, they investigate the ways that global China is a powerful shaper of landscapes and societies in Southeast Asia, as well as the multiple contingencies and agencies that condition, limit, and push back against China's infrastructural power. As we write now in 2024, China's development activities and investments beyond its borders have garnered a tremendous amount of attention from scholars, policymakers, politicians, and the general public alike. Much of that attention has focused on the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) as the primary policy vehicle for these activities and investments (see Lin et al., 2019 and Lin et al., 2021 for critical and theoretical engagements with BRI-related scholarship). The China Made project emerged in this context with the goal of exploring China's infrastructure-led development practices less from a policy perspective, or even from the view of geopolitics, and more from a fine-grained and grounded analysis of the projects themselves. We thus sought to bring a contextual and place-based perspective to our understanding of China as an emerging actor on the global development scene. We felt that such an approach depended upon an historical understanding of the role that infrastructure development has played in Chinese statecraft and in China's domestic political economy over the past several decades (Rippa & Oakes, 2023). Conceptually, we hoped such an approach would open up a space for a productive transdisciplinary conversation between the China studies and infrastructure studies fields (see e.g. Oakes, 2019; Oakes, 2021). This conversation has emphasized not simply the ways the Chinese state deploys infrastructure development as a form of power and state-making, but also the ways infrastructures themselves, as socio-technical assemblages, have agentive powers and material logics that shape environmental, social, cultural, and political life in significant ways, both within and beyond China's borders. The 2021 workshop at ARI focused on these environmental, social, cultural, and political dimensions of Chinese infrastructure projects in Southeast Asia, a region often regarded as the first segment and most important part of China's Belt and Road (Gong, 2019; Emmerson, 2020; Hiebert, 2020). Collectively, Southeast Asia is China's largest trading partner, and vice versa. But the BRI has dominated much of the analysis of China's diverse activities in Southeast Asia. In response, there has been a recognized need for ways of understanding 'how China's impacts on Southeast Asia can be better understood beyond only focusing on China-centred framings such as the BRI' (Lin & Yang, 2022: 228; see also Rowedder et al., 2023). We proceeded from the premise that Chinese infrastructure development in the region is shaped by more than China's longstanding geopolitical ambitions, desires for market expansion, and the need for a spatial fix for Chinese surplus capital. We focused particular attention on the ways that infrastructures, with their material dispositions, are capable of producing their own developmental logics, propulsions, and powers over life. While the workshop explored these issues through a broad variety of cases and analytics, the papers collected here explore the social lives of Chinese infrastructure in three broad themes: global China as a field of power; the technopolitics of infrastructure; and the spatial and temporal dimensions of infrastructure development. In this brief editorial, we explore each of these themes in general terms and comment on how they are reflected and engaged in the papers collected here. We will also provide some concluding thoughts on the role of infrastructure studies in the rapidly growing field of global China studies. A field of power is defined by attempts to influence or capture social institutions such as banking systems and energy sectors, foster patron-client relations, and, as in the focus of this section, building infrastructural power or influence by connecting and channeling communications, electricity, movement of all kinds, and other basic materials of social life. While infrastructural power thus refers to the ways infrastructural configurations shape social life, it is also a relational form of power that often exceeds the abilities of social or state actors to control and determine its effects and outcomes. This does not diminish, however, the ways states like China have effectively wielded infrastructure investment and construction to enhance their influence over society and extend their authority, even beyond their territorial borders. In approaching global China as a field of power, we follow a line of thinking, laid out initially by Ching Kwan Lee (2018; 2022a), that seeks to move beyond treating global China as an empirical object comprised of strategies, policies and projects. Instead, we treat global China as an analytical concept, a way of understanding how (and how effectively) the Chinese state wields power. Chinese power abroad is of course multifaceted and cannot be restricted to state practices. The entrepreneurial activities throughout the world of small-scale traders, shopkeepers, and manufacturers has in fact been the dominant form of Chinese influence for centuries, especially in Southeast Asia, where many generations of China's diaspora have long shaped commercial development and social change in the region (Kian, 2015; Nyiri & Tan, 2017). Much of this 'transnationalism from below' (Dittgen, 2017) exists at the edges of the formal economy and has long blurred the line between licit and illicit activity (Rippa, 2020). But Chinese influence is felt not just through economic channels (see e.g. Ling & Segre-Reinach, 2021). While we recognize this diversity of influence, we focus our discussion on the state and larger transnational corporations because of their outsized role in infrastructure development in Southeast Asia. Lee proposed three domains of practice, or modes of power, that tend to characterize China's efforts to exert influence through its global investments and development projects, most of which have involved infrastructural construction of various sorts. These are economic statecraft, patron clientelism, and symbolic domination. The first of these—economic statecraft—involves the use of economic means to achieve political and/or diplomatic objectives which might include, for example, recognition of China's territorial claims. State-owned enterprises figure prominently here, though private firms can also play a fundamental role in China's economic statecraft, as do financial institutions. Indeed, perhaps the bluntest form of economic statecraft that captures considerable attention is the use of state-backed development financing to secure influence (the so-called 'debt trap' strategy). While some scholars have argued that much of the debt-trap discourse is driven by racialized fear of the West being displaced as the world's dominant development power and neglects the role played by states that seek Chinese-financed projects or fails to carefully examine the specific motivations of Chinese companies and agencies (Carmody, 2020; The Atlantic, 2021), it cannot be denied that debt financing remains a powerful tool of economic statecraft for China (see also Lai et al., 2020). Patron clientelism has been a basic practice of Chinese statecraft since at least the founding of the PRC (Walder, 1986; Oi, 1989) and probably well before that too. There are echoes of it in the so-called tributary system which, as Lin (2009) has argued, continued as an instrument of political expediency even after the end of the Qing Dynasty in 1911. It was also a long-standing political practice along China's internal southwestern frontier, where the tusi system of cultivating native chieftainship was adopted as an indirect form of rule for centuries (Herman, 1997; Crossley, et al., 2006). In more contemporary practice, patron clientelism involves cultivating uneven interpersonal relationships with key actors in places hosting (or potentially hosting) Chinese development projects. These relationships are meant to deliver material benefits (from China) in exchange for political allegiance (from hosts). They also often have the effect of bolstering the power of local officials. Of course, such relationships are not unique to China, but have perhaps played a comparatively large role in the extension of Chinese state power. Finally, symbolic domination might be considered as the exercise of influence by shaping people's common sense, disposition, and habits of thought. While we might often think of this as 'soft power', it is important to link efforts to influence and control the discourse about China as part of the state's efforts to dominate that discourse within China, rather than simply regarding it as a tool of foreign policy or external influence, as implied by the idea of soft power (Repnikova, 2022). Spectacular infrastructure projects, new town developments, and other large-scale developments financed and built by China throughout the Global South play an outsize role in constituting the symbolic dimensions of state power. Infrastructure is, indeed, central to all of these modes of power. It is the most common 'material benefit' deployed by China in exchange for political objectives, and through which patron client relationships are cultivated. The example of technological standards provides just one illustration of this. China's ability to shape international technical standardization in a global arena of power competition has become significant. Rühlig (2022) argues that it not only helps Chinese companies but also the state more broadly, by creating lock-in effects in which host countries must rely on Chinese suppliers to maintain and further build-out their railway networks. This may be the case, for instance, in Indonesia as a result of the Jakarta-Bandung high-speed rail, in Laos, and in Ethiopia. In addition, China's projects are often regarded as symbolic markers of status and modernity in recipient countries, helping to forge popular associations of China with progress, development, and hopeful futures. As observed by Turner and her colleagues (Turner et al., 2023), China is clearly viewed as a viable avenue toward 'modernity' for many Southeast Asian countries, even if it remains dogged by a popular perception in some places of mass-producing cheap and poor-quality goods. Infrastructural power, however, has multiple forms that in some ways extend beyond ideas of national development. To understand this excess, we also treat infrastructural power as a relational form of power that does not emerge simply from 'the state' in a unidirectional way. In this, we note the way infrastructural power might be understood as a materialist reframing of what Foucault called 'biopower', in which power is emergent within and among the relations between the myriad organizations, institutions, technologies, and other apparatus that regulate and control or discipline bodies and populations. Thus, infrastructural power entails not simply state policies and strategies but a diverse collection of organizations, firms, regulatory bodies, expert systems, financial institutions, and standards. To these we could also add the materials of these infrastructures themselves: concrete, steel, wire, and even immaterial components, such as wireless signals. The 'socio-technical assemblages' that constitute infrastructural forms (Anand et al., 2018) can be understood as having the power to shape outcomes in ways that might vary from the straightforward political objectives of policy actors. Approaching global China as a field of power has bearing on a key question that animates much of the discussion in the papers collected here: to what extent can a distinct 'China model' of development be identified when considering the on-the-ground characteristics of China's infrastructure development projects in Southeast Asia? This question comes up for a number of reasons. China has at different times both eschewed and promoted the idea of a distinct China model. Although Deng Xiaoping famously admonished other countries to not follow China's model (as part of the Chinese state's efforts to promote self-determination and solidarity among Third World nations), a stance that has been repeated by Chinese leaders over the years, including Xi Jinping, there are clearly aspects of China's state-led development and modernization experience that it uses to support all three modes of power that it exerts abroad. China has grown increasingly confident in articulating a counter-vision of a poly-centric global order not dominated by the West or by the unfettered neoliberalism of global capitalism. While this vision is in some ways offered, and interpreted, as a model, the view from the ground reveals a more pragmatic approach that is seldom ideologically driven (Tang, 2020). China's approach, in short, is always embedded and localized in host countries. Tritto and Camba (2022) point out that the 'Shekou model'—named after one of the first industrial parks established in the 1980s in the Pearl River Delta—has shaped the way industrial parks in Southeast Asia have been built (with a dedicated port, residential compounds, seclusion and separated services for employees). But these parks are also highly localized by host country development priorities and by the politics that such parks generate. What China does on the ground is thus always shaped by the conditions and situations in target countries. This does not need to be understood purely as a limitation on Chinese power, however. Nor is it that outcomes not matching the 'model' are necessarily indicators of the power of the countries and communities that host Chinese projects. Agency does not always translate into benefit. As Lesutis (2021) has pointed out in analysing Chinese railway construction projects in Kenya, host state visions of enhancing territorial power via mega-project infrastructure construction are diverted by the power of Chinese companies' interference with local development objectives. But Chinese companies do not always get their way either, as made clear for instance in Dourado's (2023) critique of China Railway Eryuan Engineering Group's failed efforts to bypass local environmental regulations and other standards in its efforts to build the Brazil-Peru transcontinental railway. Harlan and Lu (2024) address the question of whether or how China exports its development model. They argue that what they call a 'cooperation-infrastructure nexus' establishes implicit narratives of a China model. This discursive model has material effects, but the outcome is always very different from what happened in China. Yet even discursively, the 'China model' remains vague for the same on-going reasons that led to Deng Xiaoping disclaiming any specific model that China sought to impose on other countries (thus, paradoxically, making it an attractive alternative 'model' compared to the West). In the specific cooperation programs they analyse in their paper, there are a variety of priorities and goals being pursued by a variety of actors. But there are some common attributes: self-reliance, governance capacity, technology innovation, and an infrastructural focus. This is similar to what has been argued by Lampton et al. (2020: 236) in their account of Chinese railway construction in Southeast Asia. They note that while there may not be a 'China model' there does seem to be a 'China approach' 'that marries strategic direction, relentless entrepreneurialism and opportunism, a willingness to work with nations as Beijing finds them (not as it wishes them), and a capacity to focus resources'. The case-study specific focus of Harlan and Lu's research demonstrates why a grounded and place-based analysis is crucial for understanding how and to what extent Chinese projects in other countries reflect China's efforts to generate an alternative to Western development, based on its own development experience as a 'model'. At the same time, these projects also demonstrate how China's seemingly ambivalent efforts to promote such an alternative model are nevertheless constrained by the practicalities of local political economies. This is not to say that 'locals' always want to do things their own way when dealing with China. Many in Laos look to China as a more appropriate development model, one worthy of emulation. But translation is complicated by transactional realities and agendas of the firms involved, by the technological necessities of the projects themselves, and by the path dependencies laid down by established patterns of governance. As Harlan and Lu point out, 'the technologies, standards, and practices of the "China model" advanced through cooperation are rarely implemented on the ground'. As Green and Yi (2023) argue in their paper, 'local conditions' does not quite capture the complex geographies and histories within which Chinese development actors operate. These need to be analysed, they point out, at multiple scales (not just locally) and through various networks. Chinese development finance flows into an inherited geographical space shaped by previous relations between China and Cambodia. At the same time, this flow is characterized by much more than a bilateral debt relationship. As they have intensified commodity rice production, Cambodian farmers have become enmeshed in a range of transnational commodity markets that shape the outcomes of China's capital investments. Green and Yi argue that paying attention to multi-scalar networks of actors, circuits of capital and struggles over water that produce irrigated landscapes, yields an analysis of global China that goes far beyond simplistic tropes of 'debt traps' and 'spatial fixes' for surplus capital accumulation. Is global China just the latest variation on the imperial logics of global capitalism? This claim is implied in the totalizing approach laid out by Hardt and Negri (2001), and it is also suggested by Gordillo's (2019) notion of the 'metropolis'. For Gordillo, China cannot be understood as existing 'outside' the vast constellation of nodes and conduits repetitively moving objects, bodies, energy, and information across national borders and continents. The idea of 'the metropolis' as the expression of capitalism's infrastructure power raises the question of the extent to which global China, as a field of power, is constrained (or even dominated) by the logics (and logistics) of global capital. In the brief discussion thus far, we have emphasized the centrality of the Chinese state, and we have deliberately evaded a broader discussion regarding the state-capital relationship in China (see Peck, 2021) along with other debates over the totalizing nature of global capitalism, 'varieties of capitalism', state capitalism, and Party-state capitalism (see e.g. Brenner et al., 2003, Pearson et al., 2022). In this context we are persuaded by Lee's (2018) argument that global China is driven by a different kind of capital that is focused less on immediate return on investment and more on the optimization of profit for a variety of objectives. This approach identifies a form of Chinese state capital that is both centrally controlled and subject to local conditions. Indeed, Lee argues that Chinese state capital is conditioned by local events and countermovements in different ways when compared with the private capital that dominates neoliberal globalization. 'As Chinese state capital was driven by state-defined objectives inclusive of, but irreducible to, profits, it was more "sticky" and place-bound than global private capital' (Lee, 2018: 155). While these papers do not weigh-in explicitly on the big questions of global capitalism and how it relates to the Chinese state and to global China, they offer ways of appreciating how Chinese companies and agencies both seek to establish their own standards and frameworks for reconfiguring the global investment and development environment, while at the same time revealing the constraints and limitations that they consistently face in these efforts. Those constraints and limitations demonstrate the reality of a global capitalism that Chinese actors must engage with rather than compete against. Yet as Green and Yi argue, reducing China's development practices to a function of the logics (and crises) of capital accumulation (i.e. the 'spatial fix' argument) is to miss most of what is driving and shaping global China. Technopolitics have been variously defined as technical projects developed with political objectives in mind (Mitchell, 2002), the ways technological systems serve as proxies for hidden political agendas (Joyce, 2003), or the political effects of socio-technical configurations of various smaller technologies such as service meter systems (Von Schnitzler, 2016). Brian Larkin has argued, in keeping with this latter framing of technopolitics, 'that infrastructures typically begin as a series of small, independent technologies with widely varying technical standards' (Larkin, 2013: 330). These smaller technologies become infrastructures 'when either one technological system comes to dominate over others or when independent systems converge into a network'. As these material and immaterial techniques and technologies are brought into connection, they enter into a dynamic relationship with political rationalities. In Larkin's conceptualization, this is important in at least two ways. First, it brings citizens and spaces into connection via technological systems that are often far removed from formal political institutions (Larkin, 2013: 328). Second, infrastructures of interlinked systems produce particular structures or atmospheres of feeling that feeds into political movements and sensibilities. All of these approaches are relevant to analysing the political effects of China's infrastructure projects. For us, a technopolitical approach is one attuned to finding the political in unexpected places, and one that works against 'the tendency to understand politics too readily in geopolitical and economic terms, overdetermining the significance of specific controversies and events' (Barry, 2013: 185). Rather than approaching the politics of China's projects in Southeast Asia as a deliberate form of economic statecraft or a kind of 'infrastructure diplomacy' (both of which are of course useful analytical frames for getting at a more overt form of politics), a more grounded and place-based approach tends to reveal the ways political effects emerge in highly specific ways that have much to do with the social relations that swirl around technical configurations. Technopolitics is, in other words, a way of analysing how infrastructure projects can generate local political effects that both constrain and enable their development. And in some cases these political effects go well beyond 'the local'. In Harlan and Lu's paper, the rhetoric of 'South-South cooperation' provides a discursive framework for China's investment projects in Laos. China's leadership views connectivity in broad terms, not just the 'hard' infrastructural kind, but also 'soft' connectivity, people-to-people connectivity and mediated events. As already noted, soft connectivity—exemplified by training programs in best practices and cooperative exchanges that represent patrons and clients on equal footing—is where much of the work articulating an alternative 'China model' gets done. These soft infrastructures have their own material effects by, for example, introducing new technologies and systems, and practices for maintaining them over a long duration, that can be transferred from China. But the effects of the projects themselves end up being highly variable and fail to align with the rhetorical claims of soft connectivity. For example, China promotes small hydropower (SHP) as an appropriate infrastructure for South-South cooperation, but existing hydropower developments in Laos, as well as the desire for greater profitability among construction firms and Lao officials alike, has resulted instead in a trend toward larger hydropower infrastructures. For Green and Yi (2023), irrigation infrastructures comprise a technopolitical network that circulates capital throughout agrarian landscapes by reassembling relations between people and nature. This network involves much more than just irrigation infrastructures but also new roads, bridges, ports, and other components that facilitate the flow of commodity rice within and beyond Cambodia. The effect of this network is to recalibrate how farmers work the land and how they interact with the market, introducing pressures of market concentration and monopolistic tendencies such that the 'irrigated landscape has become connected to market networks shot through with power at multiple scales'. In addition, investment in irrigation infrastructures have produced unintended outcomes 'arising from technical design, water scarcity, pest ecologies, and struggles over water access'. The objective of such investments have in some ways been achieved by enabling two crops per year, turning Battambang into a commodity rice producing region and thus enhancing the production of surplus value through agricultural capitalization. But these changes in the landscape, and the socio-technical relations driving those changes, have produced their own political effects, most notably in terms of contests over access to water. Irrigation infrastructure governance has developed into a 'chronic problem' for Cambodia left over after the project is built and the Chinese company collects its pay and moves on. On a national scale, investment objectives have been met, while a more local form of politics simmers. Infrastructural configurations also drive the politics swirling around the construction of the Hanoi metro in ways that are perhaps counterintuitive. As Turner, Nguyen and Hykes argue in this special section, popular opinions about the metro have been shaped more by its actual effects rather than Vietnam's historical antagonism toward China: 'it is the on-the-ground realities of this project and the unexpected events during its construction that have turned many residents against it'. And yet, those historical antagonisms were also recalibrated by the project's technopolitics. While the metro achieved a certain symbolic value as 'modern', construction itself was dominated by delays, accidents, cost-overruns, inconveniences, and displacements. These things tend to happen in almost any megaproject, but the material process of the metro's construction enlivened a latent politics of modernization that had been simmering in the background, producing a structure of feeling in line with Larkin's framing of technopolitics. The metro was part of the government's plans for a more modern Hanoi dominated by rational planning and fewer motorbikes. China's willingness to invest in this vision and thus expose itself to the broad discontent produced by the project gave the Hanoi government something of a free pass. All the papers in this special section seek to map in various ways Chinese investment patterns across multiple networks and scales of agency, and onto landscapes of historical change that significantly impact the effects of those investments. Attention to the spatial dimensions of China's infrastructure investments in Southeast Asia is important since those investments tend to be understood simply at national and global scales of states and multinational capitalism. This is not just a question of accounting for a previously neglected 'local scale' but more importantly for the connections across multiple scales that are established by infrastructural configurations. A grounded, place-based analysis, in other words, is not restricted to the local scale by any means, but demonstrates how local effects reverberate across scales. This approach is most explicitly explored by Green and Yi, but all of the projects examined in the papers (irrigation, metro rail, rubber, hydropower) stretch across multiple scales in terms of their financing, the political and policy contexts that enable them, and the social and political effects that result. There are distinct agencies associated with different scales and networks that effect, shape, and otherwise act upon these projects. Only some of these agents can be called 'Chinese' even if China is the driver of the changes taking place. Thus, attention to spatial dimensions provides a useful analytical tool for understanding the diffused and relational qualities of China's infrastructure power and how these qualities produce effects that can vary greatly from the policies and strategies that seek to wield that power for China's benefit. At the same time, attention to temporal dimensions is equally important. The outcomes of the Chinese investments explored in these papers often reflect the path-dependencies that previous infrastructures, political organizations, and economic patterns have left. These can include older agricultural infrastructures in Cambodia, existing street layouts and transportation systems in Hanoi, or hydropower construction trends that drive development toward larger and larger projects rather than 'small hydropower' that may be more appropriate in scale and cost. There are of course many different ways of conceptualizing the temporal dimensions of infrastructure, and the field has long been engaged in how infrastructures shape notions of futurity and progress, and how different infrastructural configurations entail different temporal horizons of construction, completion, maintenance, decay, and ruination. These temporalities are conditioned not only by policy or planning decisions and other governance-related factors, but also by the properties of the materials themselves. Those properties also impact the ways infrastructures may be recycled, reused and repurposed over time. The half-life of given technologies, the need for constant maintenance and Chinese-oriented service are an important part of the durative presence of Chinese-built infrastructural systems. The China Made project was initiated with the objective of addressing the absence of what Bach (2016) called the world's paradigmatic infrastructure state in much of the infrastructure studies field. We suspect that this absence was due, in part, to the lingering exceptionalist tendencies in the China studies field itself. This exceptionalism has been subject to criticism within the field for years (Lee, 2022b), but it has only been with the recent rise of a more global China that new analytical approaches and methodologies have shown how it might finally be put to rest (see e.g. Byler, 2022; Oakes, 2021; Franceschini & Loubere, 2022). The papers in this special section demonstrate in various ways how the relational nature of infrastructures provides a valuable pathway for analysing China's increasingly global presence without reducing the particularities of that presence to 'Chinese characteristics'. Such a reductionist move remains all too common as the still somewhat insular China studies field confronts the rapid integration of China's political economy into global patterns of capital circulation, accumulation, and related processes. Understanding infrastructure as linked to a global field of power is important for understanding the ability of Chinese actors to influence national and subnational systems particularly in the global South—the primary site of China's Belt and Road Initiative. This, in turn, produces a sharper understanding of the way the domestic political legitimation at local and national levels inform the cross-regional transfer of material, technology and expertise. It also demonstrates the way the surpluses of capital and labour in China's domestic economy contributes to the world system. All of this points toward a global present and future that is multipolar, and thus in greater forms of flux. The social life of Chinese infrastructures in Southeast Asia is a story that is still unfolding and that will always exceed analysis. But understanding some of the primary domains of practice and modes of power that drive these infrastructural systems offers some important points of focus for evaluating their effects and the future life of infrastructures already in motion. We would like to thank our co-conveners for the 2021 workshop: Tim Bunnell, Rachel Silvey, and Yang Yang. The staff at the Asia Research Institute deserve special mention for their fantastic technical and organizational assistance. Additional support was provided by the Asia Research Institute at the National University of Singapore and the Asian Institute at the University of Toronto. We would also like to thank all of the workshop participants who made the online format come alive despite the distance between us.
